title: 111_s3529
content: The Act may be cited as the "AMERICA Works Act" and aims to establish industry-recognized credentials for job training programs. The Workforce Investment Act of 1998 prioritizes training programs that offer industry-recognized credentials for employment and training activities. The Workforce Investment Act of 1998 prioritizes training programs that lead to credentials in high demand in the local area served. The Workforce Investment Act of 1998 prioritizes training programs leading to high-demand credentials in the local area served, as outlined in the AMERICA Works Act and the Carl D. Perkins Career and Technical Education Act of 2006. The Carl D. Perkins Career and Technical Education Act of 2006 is amended to prioritize programs leading to industry-recognized credentials in high demand areas, as outlined in the AMERICA Works Act. The Carl D. Perkins Career and Technical Education Act of 2006 is amended to prioritize career and technical education activities that support the attainment of industry-recognized credentials or certificates, with a focus on high-demand registry skill credentials. The Carl D. Perkins Career and Technical Education Act of 2006 is amended to prioritize tech-prep programs that focus on industry-recognized credentials, including high-demand registry skill credentials. "In amending the Trade Act of 1974, priority consideration for training programs leading to high-demand credentials in the local area is emphasized." SEC. 3. SKILL CREDENTIAL REGISTRY. The term "covered provision" includes specific sections from various acts, while "industry-recognized" refers to credentials accepted by companies in a sector and endorsed by a trade association. The Secretary of Labor will create a registry of nationally portable skill credentials within the industry sector, recognized by companies across multiple states for recruitment and hiring purposes. This is in line with workforce investment activities as defined in the Workforce Investment Act of 1998. The Secretary of Labor will establish a registry for nationally portable skill credentials, prioritizing credentials required by law or endorsed by the Manufacturing Institute. Additionally, industry-recognized credentials consistent with established competency models may also be listed. The Secretary will establish a registry for nationally portable skill credentials, including industry competency models and the American College Test National Career Readiness Certification. This Act does not mandate selecting programs with credentials listed in the registry. The Act and its amendments will become effective 120 days after enactment.
